nonMonitoredImpact.title: Non-monitored Impact
nonMonitoredImpact.subtitle: These outcomes are natural by-products of the primary impact above, but will not be measured or verified.

landManagementActions.title: Land Management Actions
landManagementActions.subtitle: This is how the project developers are planning to achieve the primary impact.

projects.name: Wilmot
glanceText: Improved co-benefits significantly with Soil Health ranking as excellent, Ecosystem Health as good, and Animal Welfare as excellent.

developer.name: Impact Ag
developer.description: Impact Ag utilises a variety of pathways and partners to measure and monitise natural capital on assets under management or advisory.

steward.name: Wilmot Cattle Co.
steward.description: Wilmot Cattle Company is an innovative, regenerative, grass-fed beef business.

projects.shortDescription: Wilmot Cattle Co currently operates two properties, Wilmot and Woodburn. The two properties operate cooperatively with a mix of breeding, trading, and 100% natural grass finishing enterprises.
projects.longDescription:
Wilmot is located high in the New England Tablelands in Ebor, Australia. At approximately 1,200 meters above sea level, the 1,854 hectare property has an average annual rainfall of 1,200 mm, highly fertile volcanic basalt soils, pristine spring fed, year-round natural waterways, including five waterfalls. It is a unique environment for growing cattle.

Prior to the commencement of Wilmot Cattle Company operations in 2008, the property had been conventionally managed. In 2013, a property transformation began, adopting regenerative and holistic management practices and resulting in significant gains in the overall ecological health of the farm.

Today the property is managed in an intensive rotationally-grazed system with small numbers of large mobs moving across the landscape, mimicking nature, to create ecological change and improve landscape health and biological function. At shovel depth, our soil organic carbon (SOC) has improved from ~2.5% to >4.5%, with a goal of getting it to >6% by 2023.
keyOutcomesActivities: Unique - avoiding double issuance through GIS tracking
Real - GHG impact is quantifiable and verifiable
Measurable - each credit represents one ton of CO2e
Permanent - 25 year period through reversal buffer or covenant
Additional - a new practice adopted from pre-approved list
Leakage - de minimis in agricultural land management

actions.name: Time Controlled Rotational Grazing
actions.description: Since 2013, Wilmot Cattle Co. has implemented time controlled rotational grazing at Wilmot Farm. In order to mirror natural herding behaviors, time controlled rotational grazing optimizes the number of stock in a paddock, matches the grazing period with available pasture, shortens grazing periods in each paddock, and follows these activities by long resting periods to allow the pasture to recover. When managed well, this grazing system increases groundcover, biomass, plant diversity, animal and plant nutrition, soil health, water infiltration and soil organic carbon. A more complete explanation of the science, monitoring tools and management practices is provided below.

actions.name: Decrease Paddock Size
actions.description: Decreased paddock sizes enable effective grazing at a controllable density. Wilmot Farm has adopted a paddock subdivision program with an average paddock size of 25 hectares.

actions.name: Increase Stock Density
actions.description: Carefully managed, high stock densities lead to evenly grazed pastures, nutrient recycling, increases in pasture health and performance by trampling (or recycling) a higher proportion of biomass, and evenly distributing dung and urine (nutrients).

actions.name: Monitor Pasture Growth
actions.description: Accurate measurement of pasture growth (available feed) determines the density of animals and length of time in a paddock.

actions.name: Manage Grazing Periods
actions.description: To ensure effectively implemented grazing practices and management practices records, Wilmot Farm utilizes the online tool Maia Grazing. Maia Grazing uses climatic data and field observations to determine pasture growth and optimal stocking rates, tracks stock movements, and ensures the stocking rate does not exceed the carrying capacity of each paddock.

impact.name: Soil organic carbon
impact.description: Each credit represents one ton of CO2e (1t CO2e) that has been sequestered in the soil.

impact.name: Ecosystem health
impact.description: We rank the ecosystem health based on the Costanza Framework, measuring its ability to maintain  structure (organization) and function (vigor) over time in the face of external stress (resilience).

impact.name: Animal welfare
impact.description: We rank animal welfare based on adherence to national animal welfare standards that track nutrition level, access to water, social contact and more.

impact.name: Soil health
impact.description: We rank the soil health based on Cornell University’s Soil Health Assessment looking at both micronutrients and macronutrients.

creditClass.name: Carbon Plus Grasslands (beta)
creditClass.description:
Livestock grazing covers over 3.3 billion hectares, or 25 percent of the world’s land area. Managed grazing practices can reverse land degradation, enhance net carbon sequestration, and improve soil and vegetation quality.

Under managed grazing, carbon sequestration potential is estimated between 16.4 and 26 Gt CO2e sequestered in the period between 2020-2050.

This credit is designed to significantly increase the amount of hectares under managed grazing worldwide. To that end, the methodology relies on remote sensing to substantially reduce the cost of monitoring carbon sequestration while maintaining scientific rigor.
